clinical_study.official_title: Study of Daily Life and Health

brief_summary.textblock: Adolescents will complete a 4-week intervention, during which they will either complete a kind act for others, complete a kind act for themselves, or report their daily activities three days per week. Psychological and physiological measures will be indexed before and after the intervention.

detailed_description.textblock: Stress and early adversity have been found to influence immune function via enhanced expression of the conserved transcriptional response to adversity (CTRA) genetic profile. Expression of this genetic profile was reduced in adults who completed a prosocial behavior intervention. This project aims to implement this intervention in adolescents. 90 high school students will be recruited and assigned to one of three groups (30/group). Participants will either conduct 3 acts of kindness for themselves, conduct 3 acts of kindness for others, or report about their day 3 times per week for 4 weeks. During this intervention, they will receive text messages 3 days per week instructing them to complete their respective act. Participants will provide a brief description of this act that evening, as well as complete brief surveys at the end of the week for each week of the intervention. Participants will come into the lab twice, once before and once after the 4-week intervention. During these lab sessions participants will complete survey measures, have their heart rate measured, and have a blood draw conducted by a trained phlebotomist. Participants' parents will also complete a brief survey to provide demographic information and an idea of what prosocial behaviors participants witnessed in their home. We will use these data to assess the effects of prosocial behavior on health and the psychological mechanisms underlying these effects. At the second study visit, participants will be given the opportunity to donate part of their study payment to a charity to measure prosociality. Any donations will be vetted with the psychology department's accounting group prior to making any donations in the university's name. Scott Monatlik, Director, Tax and Information Practices, at smonatlik@finance.ucla.edu or (310) 794-6724 will be contacted and information regarding the appropriate steps to take to ensure that the donation is made to an acceptable charity prior to any donations. Actual helping behavior (donations) is measured to provide an ecologically valid experimental evaluation of prosociality rather than traditional metrics of computerized, fictional giving. Conceptual frameworks from developmental and health psychology guide the hypothesis that prosocial behavior will influence adolescents.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: 90 participants will randomly be assigned to one of three interventions. Participants will complete a 4-week intervention. All outcomes will be measured before and after the intervention, and some psychological measures will be collected weekly throughout the intervention.
study_design_info.masking_description: Participants will be told that we are studying the daily lives of teens. They will not be informed of the other arms of the experiment.

primary_outcome.description: Intervention efficacy of affect will be assessed by the positive affect subscale of the Affect Adjective Checklist. Participants rate the degree to which they felt positive emotions over the past week on a scale from 1 (not at all) to 5 (extremely much). We take the mean across the 4 items such that higher scores reflect experiencing more positive affect over the week.

secondary_outcome.description: Intervention efficacy of inflammation assessed by assays of C-reactive protein.

secondary_outcome.description: Intervention efficacy of inflammation assessed by assays of IL-6.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Over 5 weeks (before intervention to 1 week after)
secondary_outcome.description: Intervention efficacy of baseline inflammation assessed by assays of the conserved transcriptional response to adversity profile of gene expression in leukocytes.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Over 5 weeks (before intervention to 1 week after)
secondary_outcome.description: Intervention efficacy of psychological flourishing assessed by Mental Health Continuum-Short Form (MHC-SF). Participants rate the degree to which they felt 20 items over the past month on a scale from 1 (never) to 6 (everyday). We take a mean across these items, with higher values representing greater psychological flourishing.

Intervention efficacy of loneliness assessed by Revised UCLA Loneliness Scale. Participants rate the degree to which 20 items are true for them on a scale from 1 (never) to 4 (often). We take a mean across these items, with higher values representing greater loneliness.

Intervention efficacy of affect will be assessed by the negative affect subscale of the Affect Adjective Checklist. Participants rate the degree to which they felt five negative emotions over the past week on a scale from 1 (not at all) to 5 (extremely much). We take the mean across the five items such that higher scores reflect experiencing more negative affect over the week.

other_outcome.description: Intervention efficacy of self esteem assessed by Self Esteem Scale. Participants rate the degree to which they agree or disagree with 10 statements on a scale from 1 (strongly disagree) to 5 (strongly agree). We took a mean across these 10 items, with higher scores indicating higher self-esteem.

Intervention efficacy of stress assessed by the Perceived Stress Scale (PSS). Participants rated the degree to which they felt stressed over the past week on 10 items on a scale from 1 (strongly disagree) to 5 (strongly agree). A mean is taken across these items, with higher scores indicating greater stress.

Intervention efficacy of health status assessed by Patient-Reported Outcomes Measurement Information System Sleep Disturbance (PROMIS-SD) Scale. Participants rate the degree to which they experienced seven symptoms over the past week on a scale from 1 (not at all) to 5 (very much) and rate their overall sleep quality from the past week on a scale from 1 (very poor) to 5 (very good). We take the mean across all items, with higher scores representing greater sleep disturbance.

Intervention efficacy of happiness assessed by Subjective Happiness Scale (SHS). Participants rate the degree to which they consider themselves happy relative to others on two items on a scale from 1 (not a very happy person) to 7 (a very happy person) as well as the degree to which they agree with two items that suggest they consider themselves a generally happy person on a scale of 1 (not at all) to 7 (a great deal). The mean across these four items was taken, with higher scores indicating greater happiness.

other_outcome.time_frame: Over 5 weeks (before intervention to 1 week after)
other_outcome.description: Intervention efficacy of inflammation assessed as the change in concentration of a variety of inflammatory cytokines (e.g., IL-6, IL-1).

other_outcome.time_frame: Over 5 weeks (before intervention to 1 week after)
other_outcome.description: Intervention efficacy of RSA assessed as the change in high-frequency heart rate variability during paced breathing.

arm_group.description: Participants will complete the 'Other-Focused Acts of Kindness Intervention' by performing acts of kindness for others. They be asked to complete 3 kind acts for others throughout the week for 4 weeks. They will receive text messages three days per week (either Tuesday, Thursday, and Saturday or Wednesday, Friday, and Sunday) and will report on their kind act later that day.

Participants will complete the 'Self-Focused Acts of Kindness Intervention' by performing acts of kindness for themselves. They be asked to complete 3 kind acts for others throughout the week for 4 weeks. They will receive text messages three days per week (either Tuesday, Thursday, and Saturday or Wednesday, Friday, and Sunday) and will report on their kind act later that day.

Participants will complete the 'Daily Reports' and be asked to report their daily activities throughout the week for 4 weeks. They will receive text messages three days per week (either Tuesday, Thursday, and Saturday or Wednesday, Friday, and Sunday) and will list activities from their day.

intervention.description: Participants engage in positive behaviors by completing acts of kindness for themselves three times per week. These acts should require effort and be outside of an individual's normal routine.
Participants engage in positive behaviors by completing acts of kindness for others three times per week. These acts should require effort and be outside of an individual's normal routine.
Participants will report their daily activities three times per week. Aside from reporting at the end of the day, no changes should be made to the individual's normal routine.
